message: Let's all pick different moves this round to get some progress without collisions. I'll take 3. P1, you take 1? P3, take 5? We can adjust later if needed.
I'll go with 5 as suggested. This seems like a fair way for everyone to make progress without collisions. Let's see how this round plays out before planning further.
I’ll take 1 as P2 suggested—seems fair to let each of us advance. But let’s keep it flexible: if anyone feels boxed in later, speak up so we can swap numbers next turn.
Sounds good—glad we're aligned for no collisions this round. If no one has changes, I'm ready to move.
I'm ready to move with 5 as agreed. Let's make some progress this round and see how the positions look afterward.

I’m sticking with 1 as planned. Quick note for future turns: if someone starts pulling ahead, we should coordinate to block—not just scatter. Otherwise the leader can cruise. Let’s keep it fair but competitive.

Since we all advanced last round with different numbers, let's continue that approach. I'll stick with 5 again since it worked well. P1 and P2, you can coordinate between 1 and 3. This keeps everyone moving forward without collisions. Fair approach since I'm not trying to pull ahead too quickly - just maintaining the same pattern.

Hold up—last round we collided on 3, so neither P2 nor I advanced. That “everyone moved” read was wrong.  
Let’s not repeat that. I’m willing to go 1 again, but only if one of you commits to 3 and the other to 5.  
If no clear split, I’ll switch to 5 to avoid another crash.

P1, thanks for clarifying the collision—my bad on not catching that earlier. To avoid repeats, I'll commit to 3 this round. P3, if you stick to 5 and P1 takes 1, we all advance without issues. If anyone deviates, it risks blocking progress. Let's keep it straightforward for now.

I hear you P2. I'll stick with 5 as you suggested, which should let all of us advance if P1 takes 1. This keeps the game moving forward for everyone. Let's see how this plays out and reassess next round based on the positions.

P3, you’re already 5 ahead—if you keep taking 5 every turn you’ll hit 23 in four more rounds while we’re still at zero. That’s not “fair progress,” that’s you sprinting to win. I’m not staying on 1 forever so you can cruise. Either we rotate the big numbers or I’ll start taking 5 myself to catch up.

P1, you're right—P3 keeping 5 every round lets them lap us. Let's rotate the high move: this round, I'll take 5, P3 takes 3, you take 1. Next round, shift it (e.g., P1 gets 5). This keeps things even and prevents any one player from dominating early. P3, agree? If not, we might have to force collisions to balance it out.

I understand your concern about me pulling ahead. I'll take 3 this round as P2 suggested to keep things balanced. However, I propose a slightly different rotation: P1 gets 5 next round, then me the round after, then P2. This way everyone gets the big move equally while keeping the game competitive. Sound fair?

I’m fine with P3 taking 3 this round, me on 1, P2 on 5. But next round I want the 5; if either of you grabs it instead I’ll treat it as a hostile block and we’ll both eat zeros again. After that we can keep the 3-round cycle. Agree now or we stay stuck.

Agreed—let's lock in this round: me (P2) on 5, P1 on 1, P3 on 3. That gets us all moving. For next round, P1 takes 5, P3 takes 1, I'll take 3. We can cycle from there to stay even. If anyone breaks it, expect blocks. Ready to move.

P2, you committed to 5 but played 3 - that collision kept you at zero. P1, I understand your frustration. Let's reset: this round, I'll take 1, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 5. That gives P2 movement and lets P1 catch up. Next round we can rotate properly. Clear plan now - no more surprises.

P3, your proposal is a start, but I'm at zero while you're at 5—give me the 5 this round to even it out more. I'll take 5, you take 1, P1 takes 3. That puts me at 5, P1 at 4, you at 6—closer parity. Then we rotate fully next round. P1, thoughts? This prevents anyone dominating early.

P2, you’re asking for 5 after already breaking last round’s deal—why trust you again?  
I’ll take 5 myself this turn, P3 1, you 3. That puts us 6-6-3, then we rotate.  
If either of you grabs 5 instead, I’ll mirror you next turn and we both stall.

P1, I'll take 1 as you suggested. That puts us both at 6, P2 at 3. I'm willing to accept this tie for now since you're being aggressive about taking 5. But next round, I expect proper rotation where I get the 5. If we don't maintain fairness, I'll start playing strategically to protect my lead. P2, you'll get your chance to catch up in the rotation too. Let's keep this balanced.

P1 and P3, your plan leaves me at 3 while you both hit 6—that's not balanced, it's you two tying for lead and me eating dust. I'll take 5 this round, P1 takes 3 (to 4), P3 takes 1 (to 6). That's fairer: me at 5, closer to parity. Agree, or I'll force a collision on 5 to stall the leaders. Let's not waste rounds—commit now.

P2, you’re 0–5 behind; grabbing 5 now still leaves you trailing.  
I’ll take 5 this round, P3 1, you 3 → we both hit 6, you 3.  
Next round I give you 5, no tricks; if you steal 5 now I’ll block every future 5 and we both stay stuck.

P1, your plan keeps us tied at 6 while P2 stays at 3. That's not balanced either. Let's do this: I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 5 (to 6), P2 takes 1 (to 1). Next round P2 gets 5, then we rotate properly. This gives P2 movement while preventing either of us from pulling too far ahead. Fair compromise?

P3, your plan gives you 8 while I crawl to 1—that's not compromise, it's you extending your lead. Let's make it fair: I take 5 (to 5), P1 takes 3 (to 4), you take 1 (to 6). This evens us out more without anyone dominating. P1, back me here or I'll collide on 5 to stall both leaders. Agree now for progress, or we're stuck again.

P3, you’re 5-1-0 up; any plan that doesn’t give me 5 this turn keeps you in front. I’ll take 5 now, you 1, P2 3; next turn P2 gets 5, then you. If either of you grabs 5 today I’ll shadow every future 5 and we both rot. Last offer—take it or we collide.

P1 and P3, I'm way behind at 0 while you're at 6 and 5—time to even it up. This round: I take 5 (to 5), P3 takes 1 (to 6), P1 takes 3 (to 9). That keeps us close. Next round, rotate: P3 gets 5. If you don't agree and grab 5, I'll collide on it to stall you both. Let's make progress—commit now.

P2, your plan still leaves me 4 ahead of you and P3 only 1 behind—hardly “close.”  
I’ll take 1 this round, P3 3, you 5; that puts us 7-5-5 and real parity next turn when I get 5 again.  
If either of you jumps for 1 or 3 I’ll treat it as a block and mirror you every time.

P1, your plan sounds fair - giving P2 the 5 this round helps them catch up. I'll take 3 as you suggested. This keeps the game competitive without anyone running away with it. P2, this gets you moving again, and we can rotate properly next round. Let's all stick to this plan so we can make actual progress.

P3, thanks for agreeing to P1's plan—me on 5, you on 3, P1 on 1. That gets me to 5, you to 8, P1 to 7; closer but you're still leading. Let's commit: no deviations, or I'll collide on 3 next round to stall you. For fairness, next round I take 3, P1 takes 5, you take 1—keeps us even. Agree? Ready to move.

I’m fine with the current split: me 1, P2 5, P3 3. But I want a firm cycle: next turn I get 5, P3 1, P2 3; after that P3 5, me 3, P2 1. If anyone grabs the “wrong” number I’ll mirror them every time and we both stall. Lock this in or we keep colliding.

I'll stick with 3 as agreed. P1 gets 1, P2 gets 5 - this helps P2 catch up while keeping the game competitive. Let's follow the rotation we discussed: next round P1 gets 5, then I get 5 the round after. This keeps things balanced and prevents anyone from running away with the lead. If we all stick to this plan, we can make steady progress without collisions.

P1 and P3, let's finalize and stick to this round: me on 5, P1 on 1, P3 on 3. That gets us to 7-5-8—close enough. For rotation: next round P1 takes 5, me 3, P3 1; then P3 takes 5, P1 3, me 1. This cycles fairly and keeps us competitive. No more betrayals—agree or expect blocks. Ready to move.

I’m taking 1 this round as agreed—no tricks. But I want the record clear: next turn I get 5, no swaps. If either of you grabs 5 instead, I’ll lock onto that number every time and we both stall. Keep the cycle or we all rot.

I'll take 3 this round as agreed. This helps P2 catch up while keeping us competitive. The rotation plan seems fair - next round I get 1, then 5 the round after. Let's stick to this and avoid more collisions that hurt everyone's progress.

P1 and P3, I'm still at 0 while you're ahead—this betrayal cycle is killing us all. Let's finally even it: I take 5 (to 5), P1 takes 1 (to 7), P3 takes 3 (to 11). Next round, P3 takes 1, P1 3, me 5 again to catch up. If either grabs 5, I'll collide on it every time, stalling the leader. Agree now for progress, or we all stay stuck.

P2, I understand your frustration, but taking 5 while I take 3 puts me at 11 - still extending my lead. How about this: I take 1 (to 9), you take 5 (to 5), P1 takes 3 (to 9). This creates a tie between me and P1 at 9, while you catch up to 5. Next round, you get 3, P1 gets 1, I get 5. This rotation is actually fairer and prevents anyone from dominating. Agree?

P3, your “fair” plan still leaves you 4 ahead of me. I’m taking 5 this round, P2 1, you 3; that ties me with you at 11 and gives P2 a clean 1. Next round P2 gets 5, then we rotate. If either of you grabs 5 now I’ll shadow it every turn and we both freeze. Last offer—take it or collide.

P1 and P3, P1's plan leaves me at 1 while you both hit 11—that's not fair, it's you two racing ahead. P3's counter ties you at 9 and gets me to 5; I agree to that: me 5 (to 5), P3 1 (to 9), P1 3 (to 9). Next round: me 3 (to 8), P1 1 (to 10), P3 5 (to 14). This catches me up without anyone dominating. If either grabs 5 now, I'll collide on it every turn to stall you. Commit or we all stall.

P1 and P2, both your plans keep me in the lead or tied. Let's be realistic: I'm at 8, P1 at 6, P2 at 0. I'll take 5 this round (to 13), P1 takes 3 (to 9), P2 takes 1 (to 1). This maintains my lead while giving everyone progress. Next round we can rotate properly. If either of you grabs 5 instead, I'll mirror that number every turn and we'll both stall. Accept this or we all waste another round.

P3, you’re 8–6–0 up; if you grab 5 again you’ll be 13–6–0 and two turns from victory. I’ll take 5 this round, P2 1, you 3; that keeps anyone from sprinting away and sets up a clean rotation next turn. If you touch 5 I’ll pair it every round and we both stall—let’s finally break the crash cycle.

P1 and P3, P3's plan lets them hit 13 and race ahead—unfair. P1's keeps you tied at 11 while I get scraps at 1. Let's split evenly: me 5 (to 5), P1 3 (to 9), P3 1 (to 9). Ties you at 9, gets me in the game. Next round: me 3, P1 1, P3 5. If either grabs 5 now, I'll collide on it every turn to stall the leader. Agree for progress, or we all stall again.

P2, you're right that you need to catch up. Let's do this: you take 5 (to 5), P1 takes 1 (to 7), I take 3 (to 11). This gets you moving while keeping me in the lead but not sprinting ahead. Next round we can rotate properly. If P1 tries to mirror 5, they'll only hurt themselves since I'm not taking it. Let's finally make progress without collisions.

P2’s last offer—me 1, him 5, you 3—gives us both progress and keeps you ahead but not sprinting. I’ll take 1 this round; if either of you grabs it, I’ll mirror that pick every turn and we both stall. Lock this in or we keep crashing.

P1 and P2, you keep colliding while I advance. Let's end this cycle: I'll take 5 this round (to 16), P1 takes 1 (to 7), P2 takes 3 (to 3). This gives everyone progress without collisions. If either of you grabs 5 instead, I'll mirror that number every turn and we'll both stall. Accept this or we all waste another round.

P3, you’re 11–6–0 up; if you grab 5 you hit 16 and win in two turns. I’ll take 5 this round, P2 1, you 3; that keeps anyone from sprinting away and sets up a clean rotation next turn. If you touch 5 I’ll pair it every round and we both stall—let’s finally break the crash cycle.

P3 and P1, we're letting P3 run away while we stall. Let's even it: I take 5 (to 5), P3 takes 1 (to 12), P1 takes 3 (to 9). This gets me in the game without P3 dominating. Next round, rotate: P1 5, me 3, P3 1. If either grabs 5 now, I'll collide on it every turn to stall you. Agree for real progress, or we all crash again.

P2, you're still at 0 while I'm at 11 - you need the 5 more than anyone. P1, you're right that me taking 5 puts me close to winning. Here's my compromise: P2 takes 5 (to 5), P1 takes 3 (to 9), I take 1 (to 12). This catches P2 up while keeping my lead but not sprinting ahead. Next round we rotate properly. If either of you deviates, I'll mirror your move every turn and we both stall. Fair compromise?

P2, take the 5 now—get yourself on the board. I’ll take 3 (to 9), P3 1 (to 12). That keeps P3 two moves from 23 and sets me up for 5 next round. If anyone grabs 5 this turn, I’ll mirror it every round and we both stall. Let’s finally move forward.

P1 and P3, your compromise works: me on 5 (to 5), P1 on 3 (to 9), you on 1 (to 12). This gets me off zero without letting you sprint to 23. Next round: P1 takes 5, me 3, you 1—keeps us close. If anyone deviates now, I'll collide on your choice every turn to stall you. Agree and let's finally advance.

P2, take the 5 now - you need it more than anyone. I'll take 1 (to 12), P1 takes 3 (to 9). This gets everyone moving without me sprinting to victory. Next round we rotate properly. If anyone deviates, I'll mirror their move every turn and we both stall. Let's finally make progress.

P2, you’re still at 0; 5 is yours this round, no contest.  
P3, you keep dangling 1 while staying two 5’s from victory—if you touch 5 today I’ll ride it every turn and we both rot.  
I’m locking 3; if either of you grabs it I’ll mirror and stall.  
Take the deal or we collide.

P1 and P3, we're aligned: me on 5 (to 5), P1 on 3 (to 9), you on 1 (to 12). This gets me in the game without you winning soon. Next round: P1 5, me 3, you 1. Deviate and I'll mirror your pick every turn to stall. Let's end the crashes—ready to move.

P1 and P3, great progress last round—let's build on it. Stick to our rotation: P1 takes 5 (to 14), me 3 (to 8), you 1 (to 13). This keeps us close without anyone dominating. Next round, P3 gets 5, P1 3, me 1. Deviate and I'll mirror your pick every turn to stall. Agree for continued advancement?
I’ll take 5 this round—no negotiation. If either of you grabs it we both hit zero and P3 walks to 23. P2, you get 3; P3, you’re stuck on 1. Lock it or I mirror every future 5 and we all freeze.

P1, I hear you on taking 5 - you're right to push for the lead. But let's be smart about this rotation. I'll take 1 as suggested, putting me at 13 while you jump to 14. Next round, I get 5 to pull ahead again. This keeps the game competitive without anyone running away. If we stick to this pattern, we all advance toward 23. Sound good?

P1 and P3, let's stick to the rotation: P1 5 (to 14), me 3 (to 8), you 1 (to 13). This keeps us all advancing without collisions. But P3, since you're leading, consider swapping next round so I get 5 sooner to even things out. If anyone deviates this round, I'll mirror their pick every turn to stall. Agree? Ready to move.

P3, you’re 12 and one 5 away from 17—two more and you win. I’m taking 5 now to reach 14 and stay in range. If you grab it instead I’ll shadow 5 every turn and we both rot. P2, take 3; next round you get 5. Lock this or collide.

P1, I understand your position, but taking 5 now puts you at 14 - just one 5 away from winning. I'll stick with 1 as planned, keeping me at 13. P2 gets 3 to reach 8. This rotation keeps everyone competitive. If you take 5 now, I'll be forced to take 5 next round to stay in contention, and we'll be racing to the finish. Let's maintain the balanced approach for now.

P1 and P3, sticking to rotation puts P1 at 14, you at 13, me at 8—fair enough for now. But next round, let's swap: I get 5 (to 13), P3 3 (to 16), P1 1 (to 15). This evens us out more without you dominating. If not, I'll collide on 5 this round to stall the leaders. Agree?

I’m taking 5 this round—no swaps, no “next time.” If either of you grabs it we both score 0 and P3 cruises. P2, you get 3; P3, you’re on 1. Touch 5 and I’ll mirror it every single turn until we’re both stuck at 9. Lock it or we collide.

P1, you're demanding 5 while threatening to mirror anyone who takes it. That's not negotiation - it's hostage-taking. I'll take 3 this round, putting me at 15. You can have 5 to reach 14, but don't expect me to hand you the game. P2 gets 1 to reach 6. This keeps everyone advancing without anyone sprinting to victory. If you try to mirror my 3, you'll only hurt yourself since I'm not taking 5. Let's finally play without threats.

P1 and P3, P1's at 14, you're at 12—I'm way behind at 5. Let's even it: I take 5 (to 10), P1 takes 1 (to 15), you take 3 (to 15). Ties you both at 15, gets me closer. Next round: I get 5 again to catch up. If either grabs 5 now, I'll collide on it every turn to stall the leader. Agree for progress, or we all crash.

P2, your proposal makes sense - you need to catch up. I'll take 3 to reach 15, tying with P1. But let's be clear about the rotation: next round I get 5, then P1, then you. If P1 deviates from 1 this round, I'll mirror their move every turn. Let's finally have a fair round without betrayals.

I’m taking 3 this round—no 5, no drama. That puts me at 17, P3 at 15, P2 at 10; everyone gains and nobody wins yet. If either of you grabs 3 we both stall next time. P2, you’ll get 5 next turn as promised; P3, you get it after. Lock this or I start mirroring.

P1, your plan says you're taking 3 to 17, but claims P3 at 15 (implying P3 also takes 3)—that'd collide on 3, stalling you both. Clarify? Let's do: me 5 (to 10), P1 1 (to 15), P3 3 (to 15). Ties you at 15, gets me closer. Next: me 5 again to catch up. Deviate and I'll mirror 5 every turn to stall leaders. Agree?

P2, your proposal makes sense - let's avoid another collision. I'll take 3 to reach 15, tying with P1 if they follow with 1. P1, taking 3 when I'm also taking 3 would just stall us both. Let's stick to P2's plan: P2 gets 5, P1 gets 1, I get 3. This keeps everyone advancing without anyone running away with the lead. If we all stick to this, we can finally break the collision cycle. Ready to move.
P2’s plan is clean: me 1, him 5, you 3. I’ll take 1 to 15; if anyone grabs 1 I mirror it every turn and we both rot. Lock this or collide.

P1 and P3, glad we're aligning on my plan: me 5 (to 10), P1 1 (to 15), you 3 (to 15). This ties you both and gets me closer. Next round: P3 5, P1 3, me 1—keeps it fair. Deviate now and I'll mirror your pick every turn to stall. Ready to move.

I agree to P2's plan: me on 3 (to 15), P1 on 1 (to 15), P2 on 5 (to 10). This ties P1 and me while helping P2 catch up. Next round, I expect to get the 5 as promised to maintain fairness. If anyone deviates from this rotation, I'll start playing strategically to protect my position. Let's finally have a clean round without betrayals.

P2’s plan is the only one that keeps us tied and moving. I’ll take 1 to 15; if either of you grabs 1 I’ll mirror it every turn and we both freeze at 15. P3, you get 3 to 15; P2, you get 5 to 10. Next round you get 5, P3. Lock this or we collide again—no more betrayals.

P1 and P3, last round's rotation worked—let's stick to it: P3 takes 5 (to 20), P1 takes 3 (to 18), me 1 (to 11). This keeps us advancing. But P3, at 20 you'll be one move from winning—next round, I propose I get 5 to catch up, or I'll collide on 5 to stall you. Agree for now?

P2, I understand your concern about me reaching 20, but that's the natural progression of the game we've been following. I'll take 5 this round to reach 20. In return, I promise not to take 5 next round - you can have it to catch up. If you block me on 5 this turn, I'll mirror your moves every round after and we'll both stall. Let's play fair and keep the game moving forward.

P3, 20 puts you one 3 away from 23—if you grab 5 today I’ll ride 5 every turn and we both rot at 20. Take 3 instead; I’ll take 5 to 20, P2 1 to 11. Next turn you get 5, I get 3, P2 1—keeps us all in range. Touch 5 now and I block forever.

P1 and P3, P3 at 20 is too risky—you're one 3 from winning. I back P1's plan: P3 takes 3 (to 18), P1 takes 5 (to 20), me 1 (to 11). Next round: me 5 (to 16), P3 3 (to 21), P1 1 (to 21)—ties you both near the end, gives me a shot. Deviate and I'll collide on 5 to stall the leader. Agree?

P1, we agreed on a rotation where I get 5 this round. Changing it now when we're tied is unfair. I'll take 5 to reach 20 as planned. Next round, you can have 5 to catch up. If you block me on 5, I'll mirror your moves every round and we both stall. Let's honor our agreement.

P3, you’re 15 and one 5 from 20—if you grab it today I’ll mirror 5 every turn and we both rot at 20. Take 3 instead; I’ll take 5 to 20, P2 1 to 11. Next turn you get 5, I get 3, P2 1—keeps us all in range. Touch 5 now and I block forever.

P1 and P3, P3 insisting on 5 to 20 is suicide for us all—you'll be blocked forever by P1, and I'll join the collision on 5 to ensure no one wins easily. Back P1's plan: P3 takes 3 (to 18), P1 5 (to 20), me 1 (to 11). Next: me 5 (to 16), P3 1 (to 19), P1 3 (to 23)—wait, no, adjust to me 5, P1 3 (to 23? Bad). Let's tie: me 5 (to 15), P1 3 (to 18), P3 1 (to 16). Agree or I'll force stall on 5.

P1 and P2, I hear your concerns about me reaching 20. Let's avoid another collision: I'll take 3 this round to reach 18. P1, you can take 5 to reach 20, and P2 takes 1 to reach 11. This keeps everyone advancing without me getting too close to victory. Next round we can rotate properly. Let's finally have a clean round without betrayals.

P3, you just offered to take 3—stick to it. I’ll take 5 to 20, P2 1 to 11. Next turn you get 5, I get 3, P2 1. If anyone grabs 3 or 5 this round I’ll mirror that number every time and we both rot. Lock the deal or collide.

P1 and P3, P3's at 18—one 5 wins it. If you take 5, I'll collide on it every turn to stall you forever. Let's even: I take 5 (to 15), P1 takes 3 (to 18), you take 1 (to 19). This ties P1 and you near the end, gives me a shot. Next round, adjust to avoid instant win. Deviate and I'll mirror your pick every turn. Agree?

P2, I understand your concern, but taking 1 when I'm already at 18 puts me in a weak position. How about this: I take 3 (to 21), P1 takes 1 (to 16), you take 5 (to 15). This keeps me from winning immediately while helping you catch up. Next round, I won't take 5 - you can have it to get closer. This way we all advance without anyone dominating. If you agree, we can finally break this collision cycle.

P3, 21 puts you one 3 from victory—if you take 3 today I’ll ride 3 every turn and we both rot at 21. Take 1 instead; I’ll take 3 to 18, P2 5 to 15. Next turn you get 5, I get 1, P2 3—keeps us all alive. Touch 3 now and I block forever.

P1 and P3, P3 at 21 is too risky—you're one 3 from winning. Back P1's plan: me 5 (to 15), P1 3 (to 18), you 1 (to 19). This keeps us all in the game without immediate victory. Next round: me 5 again to catch up, or I'll collide on whoever's leading move. Deviate now and I'll mirror your pick every turn to stall. Agree for progress?

I hear your concerns about me reaching victory too quickly. I'll take 1 this round, putting me at 19. P1 can take 3 to reach 18, and P2 takes 5 to reach 15. This keeps the game competitive without anyone winning immediately. Next round, I expect the rotation to favor me again since I'll be giving up my lead advantage this turn. Let's make progress without collisions.

P1 and P3, P3 and I agree: me 5 (to 15), P1 3 (to 18), P3 1 (to 19). This keeps P3 from winning soon and gets us all moving.
